Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = u(t) + iv(t) \\), where \\( u(t) \\) and \\( v(t) \\) are real-valued functions of time t, governed by the differential equations \\( \\dot{u} = -v \\) and \\( \\dot{v} = u + \\alpha v \\), where \\( \\alpha \\) is a real constant. We also consider the impact of the Laplace transformation \\( L \\) applied to \\( z(t) \\).

If at a specific time \\( t_1 \\), an impulse \\( \\delta(t - t_1) \\) is added to \\( u(t) \\), will the endpoint Laplace transform \\( L(z(T)) \\) for T > t_1 depend solely on the original differential equations and not on the intervention?
Explanation: The intervention with the impulse modifies \\( u(t) \\) at time \\( t_1 \\), affecting the subsequent evolution of both \\( u(t) \\) and \\( v(t) \\) under their differential equations. This change will be reflected in the Laplace transform of the function at any later time T, making the resultant transform dependent on the nature and timing of the intervention as well as the original dynamics.
